#Text=Simon Kooper
#Text=Simon Kooper , Nama name : ǃGomxab , ( before 1860 – 31 January 1913 ) was the Captain of the ǃKharakhoen ( Fransman Nama ) , a subtribe of the Nama people in Namibia from 1863 to 1909 .
#Text=He became famous for leading the Nama in the Herero and Nama War of 1904 – 1907 .
#Text=Early life
#Text=Kooper was born in Pella in the Northern Cape . [ 1 ]
#Text=It is not known when his clan moved to South-West Africa but in the mid-1850s the ǃKharakhoen under Piet Koper already resided there . [ 2 ]
#Text=At that time the ǃKharakhoen were one of the Nama clans allied to the Orlam Afrikaners at Windhoek .
#Text=When this alliance was defeated by merchant Andersson 's private army in the Battle of Otjimbingwe on 15 June 1863 , Piet Koper was killed and Simon Kooper ascended to chieftaincy . [ 2 ]
#Text=Kooper was looking for a place for his clan to settle permanently . Only in 1889 could a missionary be found to stay with them .
#Text=The Fransman tribe settled at Gochas with him [ 2 ] which since then is their clan 's main settlement . [ 3 ]
#Text=Conflict with Imperial Germany

#Text=After supporting the ǀKhowesin ( Witbooi Nama ) under Hendrik Witbooi in their eventually unsuccessful resistance attempt towards German colonialism in South-West Africa , Kooper was forced to sign a protection treaty with the German Empire , represented by Governor Theodor Leutwein .
#Text=This treaty was in effect until the Herero and Nama War of 1904 – 1907 began in which Kooper sided with Witbooi again . [ 1 ]

#Text=The Germans defeated the Nama in the Battle of Swartfontein on 15 January 1905 and forced them to flee first into the Kalahari Desert and then to recede into Bechuanaland , the British colony that later became Botswana .
#Text=From there they repeatedly and for several years mounted guerrilla -style attacks at the colony 's Schutztruppe ( Protection Force ) , [ 1 ] actions that made Kooper raise to fame . [ 2 ]
#Text=After Witooi 's death end of October 1905 , Kooper and Jakob Morenga took over the leadership of the Nama uprising .
#Text=When Morenga was captured by the British in 1906 , Kooper alone led the Nama activities against the Germans .
#Text=He was imprisoned at Shark Island near Lüderitz in 1907 but escaped into the Karas Mountains where Morenga had used the old Nama fortress ǁKhauxaǃnas as hideout for his rebels . [ 4 ]
#Text=Kooper was the last Nama leader still to fight against the Germans until 1908 , and the only one never to be captured again after his escape from Shark Island .
#Text=German troops launched several attacks at his group .
#Text=In the last of these pursuits at Seatsub in March 1908 , most of the Nama under Kooper were killed and his wife was taken prisoner , but he managed to flee again . [ 1 ]
#Text=This raid contravened the international law of the time because it took place outside German jurisdiction .
#Text=German writers Hans Grimm and Fritz von Unruh took this incident as basis for one of their literary works , respectively , which made this episode known to the German public . [ 2 ]

#Text=After this last attempt to capture him , German and British colonial forces negotiated a ceasefire , granting an annual allowance for the rest of his life in return for the cessation of all hostilities from his side . [ 1 ]
#Text=Simon Kooper received 100 £ in 1908 , 75 £ in 1909 and 60 £ in the years thereafter from this agreement .
#Text=He died in Lokgwabe , Botswana , on 31 January 1913 . [ 1 ]
